mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\frac{P^{\prime}(\omega)}{P_{ac}(\omega)}=G_{p}(\omega)e^{j\varphi(\omega)}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>P</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>G</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>φ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="I=10\log\left(\dfrac{\sum\limits_{p=1}^{N}\left(a_{2p+1}\right)^{2}}{\sum%
\limits_{p=1}^{N}\left(a_{2p}\right)^{2}}\right)," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>N</mi></munderover><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>p</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>N</mi></munderover><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
with $U'$ and $V_{ac}$ the Fourier transform of $u'$ and $v_{ac}$, respectively. In the present study the gain $G_u$ and the phase $\phi$ are considered as the two control parameters of the coupling. They are varied independently without taking care of their physical origins. It highlights the effects of these two variables on the model.



In the initial model\cite{Auvray2012}, the jet instabilities are triggered by the transverse acoustic velocity near the flue exit. This external perturbation is anti-symmetric and only the anti-symmetric unstable mode is then triggered. This has been confirmed by several experimental observations\cite{Fabre2000}. Taking account of the fluctuating part of the velocity $u'$, another excitation for the jet instabilities is added. The effect of this perturbation on the jet is studied in the next section. 



\subsection{Effect of fluctuating velocity on the jet instabilities}
Even if it remains an academic situation, the study of the instabilities of an infinite plane jet for incompressible parallel and non viscous flow still provides insights on the instability mechanisms that occur during flute operation for a finite extent and roughly plane jet.

The theoretical jet is assumed to flow along $\mathbf{x}$ direction. The cross-stream profile $U(y)$ along $\mathbf{y}$ direction is assumed to be a Bickley profile:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\frac{U^{\prime}(\omega)}{V_{ac}(\omega)}=G_{u}(\omega)e^{j\phi(\omega)}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>U</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>V</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>G</mi><mi>u</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $\langle u \rangle$ is the centerline velocity and $b$ the half-width which is constant in the case of a non viscous flow. A perturbation flow $\mathbf{u} = u \mathbf{x} + v \mathbf{y}$ is added to the mean flow. The linear stability analysis consists in finding a propagative solution of the perturbation field $\mathbf{u} = \hat{\mathbf{u}} e^{i(\omega t-\alpha x)}$. Such a perturbation flow is ruled by the equation of Rayleigh\cite{Mattingly1971}:
prevtext:
with $U'$ and $V_{ac}$ the Fourier transform of $u'$ and $v_{ac}$, respectively. In the present study the gain $G_u$ and the phase $\phi$ are considered as the two control parameters of the coupling. They are varied independently without taking care of their physical origins. It highlights the effects of these two variables on the model.



In the initial model\cite{Auvray2012}, the jet instabilities are triggered by the transverse acoustic velocity near the flue exit. This external perturbation is anti-symmetric and only the anti-symmetric unstable mode is then triggered. This has been confirmed by several experimental observations\cite{Fabre2000}. Taking account of the fluctuating part of the velocity $u'$, another excitation for the jet instabilities is added. The effect of this perturbation on the jet is studied in the next section. 



\subsection{Effect of fluctuating velocity on the jet instabilities}
Even if it remains an academic situation, the study of the instabilities of an infinite plane jet for incompressible parallel and non viscous flow still provides insights on the instability mechanisms that occur during flute operation for a finite extent and roughly plane jet.

The theoretical jet is assumed to flow along $\mathbf{x}$ direction. The cross-stream profile $U(y)$ along $\mathbf{y}$ direction is assumed to be a Bickley profile:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="U(y)=\dfrac{\langle u\rangle}{\cosh^{2}\dfrac{y}{b}}~{}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>U</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mfrac><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>u</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>cosh</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁡</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>y</mi><mi>b</mi></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></mfrac></mpadded></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $\omega$ is a real driving pulsation, $\alpha = \alpha_r + i \alpha_i$ the complex wave number and $c_p=\omega/\alpha_r$ the phase velocity. This equation is subject to the boundary conditions:
prevtext: where $\langle u \rangle$ is the centerline velocity and $b$ the half-width which is constant in the case of a non viscous flow. A perturbation flow $\mathbf{u} = u \mathbf{x} + v \mathbf{y}$ is added to the mean flow. The linear stability analysis consists in finding a propagative solution of the perturbation field $\mathbf{u} = \hat{\mathbf{u}} e^{i(\omega t-\alpha x)}$. Such a perturbation flow is ruled by the equation of Rayleigh\cite{Mattingly1971}:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\hskip-30.0pt\left[U(y)-\frac{\omega}{\alpha}\right]\left[\frac{d^{2}\mathbf{v%
}(y)}{dy^{2}}-\alpha^{2}\mathbf{u}(y)\right]-\frac{d^{2}U(y)}{dy^{2}}\mathbf{u%
}(y)=0," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo lspace="0pt">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>U</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mi>ω</mi><mi>α</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>𝐯</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>-</mo><mrow><msup><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>𝐮</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>U</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mi>𝐮</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: where $\omega$ is a real driving pulsation, $\alpha = \alpha_r + i \alpha_i$ the complex wave number and $c_p=\omega/\alpha_r$ the phase velocity. This equation is subject to the boundary conditions:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\mathbf{u}^{\prime}(\pm\infty)=\mathbf{u}(\pm\infty)=0." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>𝐮</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo>±</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>𝐮</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo>±</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $V_{ac}$ and $\Delta P$ are the Fourier transforms of $v_{ac}$ and $\Delta p$, respectively. The resonator part, \textit{i.e.} the admittance, is described as a modal acoustic admittance:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="Y=\frac{V_{ac}}{\Delta P}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>Y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>V</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>P</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $Y_n$, $\varepsilon_n$ and $\omega_n$ are the amplitude, the damping coefficient and the pulsation of the n-th mode, respectively. The non-linear losses, due to the constriction which yields the formation of a free jet every half acoustic period, are written as a pressure drop across the window:
prevtext: where $V_{ac}$ and $\Delta P$ are the Fourier transforms of $v_{ac}$ and $\Delta p$, respectively. The resonator part, \textit{i.e.} the admittance, is described as a modal acoustic admittance:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="Y=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{j\omega Y_{n}}{\omega_{n}^{2}-\omega^{2}+j%
\varepsilon_{n}\omega_{n}\omega}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>Y</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mfrac><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>Y</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>ω</mi><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ε</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ω</mi></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
with $\alpha_{vc}=0.6$ a \textit{vena contracta} coefficient. This pressure drop will be added to the source pressure difference.

The exciter part is split into two distinct parts: the birth, growth and convection of the jet instability from the flue exit to the labium and the jet/labium interaction as a mass injection from both sides of the labium.

\smallskip
\noindent \textit{Regarding the antisymmetric perturbations}
\smallskip

Either spreading or not, the jet is described by a unique variable: its center position denoted $\eta(x,t)$. The development of linear anti-symmetric instabilities from the flue exit to the labium is assumed to be well described by the center position of the jet along the same path. As for the perturbation field of the linear stability analysis, the center position is then described as a propagative solution, function of $t-x/c_p^{(a)}$ where $c_p^{(a)}$ is the phase velocity of the anti-symmetric perturbation. The issue of the triggering of the jet perturbation is still an open question, but different authors\cite{Blanc2014,DelaCuadra2005,Fabre2000} agree that the jet is mainly perturbed at the separation point of the flow ($x\simeq 0$) by the acoustic velocity field. Based on flow visualisations, de la Cuadra\cite{DelaCuadra2005,DelaCuadra2007} proposed an expression of the jet center line as a propagative function:
prevtext: where $Y_n$, $\varepsilon_n$ and $\omega_n$ are the amplitude, the damping coefficient and the pulsation of the n-th mode, respectively. The non-linear losses, due to the constriction which yields the formation of a free jet every half acoustic period, are written as a pressure drop across the window:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Delta p_{los}=-\frac{1}{2}\rho_{0}\frac{v_{ac}|v_{ac}|}{\alpha_{vc}^{2}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>p</mi><mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>v</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mrow><msubsup><mi>α</mi><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: with $-\alpha_i^{(a)} \sim 0.3/h$ the anti-symmetric growth rate, $h$ the height from which the jet emerges and $c_p^{(a)} \sim 0.4 \langle u \rangle$ the anti-symmetric phase velocity and where $\eta_0(t)$ is an ``initial perturbation'' at $x=0$. This expression is only valid a few characteristic distances $h$ downstream so that the initial perturbation $\eta_0$ has no specific physical meaning except as an empirical fit to the data. De la Cuadra found for his experiments:
prevtext:
with $\alpha_{vc}=0.6$ a \textit{vena contracta} coefficient. This pressure drop will be added to the source pressure difference.

The exciter part is split into two distinct parts: the birth, growth and convection of the jet instability from the flue exit to the labium and the jet/labium interaction as a mass injection from both sides of the labium.

\smallskip
\noindent \textit{Regarding the antisymmetric perturbations}
\smallskip

Either spreading or not, the jet is described by a unique variable: its center position denoted $\eta(x,t)$. The development of linear anti-symmetric instabilities from the flue exit to the labium is assumed to be well described by the center position of the jet along the same path. As for the perturbation field of the linear stability analysis, the center position is then described as a propagative solution, function of $t-x/c_p^{(a)}$ where $c_p^{(a)}$ is the phase velocity of the anti-symmetric perturbation. The issue of the triggering of the jet perturbation is still an open question, but different authors\cite{Blanc2014,DelaCuadra2005,Fabre2000} agree that the jet is mainly perturbed at the separation point of the flow ($x\simeq 0$) by the acoustic velocity field. Based on flow visualisations, de la Cuadra\cite{DelaCuadra2005,DelaCuadra2007} proposed an expression of the jet center line as a propagative function:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\eta(x,t)=e^{-\alpha_{i}^{(a)}x}\eta_{0}(t-x/c_{p}^{(a)})," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>η</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>α</mi><mi>i</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>η</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>/</mo><msubsup><mi>c</mi><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $v_{ac}$ is the transverse acoustic velocity near the separation point (at $x=0$). The values of the growth factor $\alpha_i^{(a)}$ and the phase velocity $c_p^{(a)}$ vary from one condition to another but remain of this order of magnitude, in agreement with the linear stability analysis presented in the previous section.

\smallskip
\noindent \textit{Adding the symmetric perturbations}
\smallskip


When the velocity profile at the flue exit oscillates because of the acoustic coupling with the vocal tract, symmetric instabilities are expected to arise. As for the anti-symmetric instability that is assumed to modify only the jet center position, the symmetric instability is assumed to modify only the half width of the jet $b$ by adding a perturbation $b'(x,t)$. As for the anti-symmetric case the perturbation is assumed to be described by a propagative solution function of $t-x/c_p^{(s)}$ where $c_p^{(s)}$ is now the phase velocity of the symmetric unstable mode. Similarly, the half width perturbation can be written:
prevtext: with $-\alpha_i^{(a)} \sim 0.3/h$ the anti-symmetric growth rate, $h$ the height from which the jet emerges and $c_p^{(a)} \sim 0.4 \langle u \rangle$ the anti-symmetric phase velocity and where $\eta_0(t)$ is an ``initial perturbation'' at $x=0$. This expression is only valid a few characteristic distances $h$ downstream so that the initial perturbation $\eta_0$ has no specific physical meaning except as an empirical fit to the data. De la Cuadra found for his experiments:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\frac{\eta_{0}(t)}{h}=\frac{v_{ac}(t)}{\langle u\rangle}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>η</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mi>h</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>v</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>u</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: with $\alpha_i^{(s)}$ and $c_p^{(s)}$ the growth factor and the phase velocity of the symmetric mode and $b_0(t)$ an ``initial perturbation'' of the jet thickness. The initial perturbation can be written, in first approximation, in the same form as the anti-symmetric perturbation:
prevtext:
where $v_{ac}$ is the transverse acoustic velocity near the separation point (at $x=0$). The values of the growth factor $\alpha_i^{(a)}$ and the phase velocity $c_p^{(a)}$ vary from one condition to another but remain of this order of magnitude, in agreement with the linear stability analysis presented in the previous section.

\smallskip
\noindent \textit{Adding the symmetric perturbations}
\smallskip


When the velocity profile at the flue exit oscillates because of the acoustic coupling with the vocal tract, symmetric instabilities are expected to arise. As for the anti-symmetric instability that is assumed to modify only the jet center position, the symmetric instability is assumed to modify only the half width of the jet $b$ by adding a perturbation $b'(x,t)$. As for the anti-symmetric case the perturbation is assumed to be described by a propagative solution function of $t-x/c_p^{(s)}$ where $c_p^{(s)}$ is now the phase velocity of the symmetric unstable mode. Similarly, the half width perturbation can be written:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="b^{\prime}(x,t)=e^{-\alpha_{i}^{(s)}x}b_{0}(t-x/c_{p}^{(s)})," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>b</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>α</mi><mi>i</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>b</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>/</mo><msubsup><mi>c</mi><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
with $\sigma$ a proportionality coefficient and $u'$ the fluctuating part of the centerline velocity of the jet described in the previous section. The parameter $\sigma$ can be roughly estimated by assuming momentum conservation between an oscillating Poiseuille profile at the flue exit ($x=0$) and a Bickley profile established downstream, as well as conservation of the centerline velocity (see appendix \ref{app:sigma}). The proportionality coefficient $\sigma$ remains a sensitive parameter that further flow visualisations could focus on.

Finally, the total jet velocity profile at the labium is obtained by combining the transverse displacement due to the anti-symmetric perturbation and the modulation of the thickness due to the symmetric perturbation:
prevtext: with $\alpha_i^{(s)}$ and $c_p^{(s)}$ the growth factor and the phase velocity of the symmetric mode and $b_0(t)$ an ``initial perturbation'' of the jet thickness. The initial perturbation can be written, in first approximation, in the same form as the anti-symmetric perturbation:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E13.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\frac{b_{0}(t)}{h}=\sigma\frac{u^{\prime}(t)}{\langle u\rangle}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>b</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mi>h</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>u</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>u</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Once it reaches the labium, the jet is assumed to split into two flows $Q_{in}$ and $Q_{out}$ going toward the interior of the instrument and outwards, respectively. Each flux can be split into a steady and a fluctuating components: $Q_{in} = \langle Q_{in} \rangle + Q_{in}'$ and $Q_{out} = \langle Q_{out} \rangle + Q_{out}'$. The flux are assumed to be injected at specific points, behind the labium, and are separated by an acoustic distance $\delta_d=(4\sqrt{2hW})/\pi$, which is also a sensitive parameter of the model\cite{Verge1994a}. This distance being small compared to the acoustic wavelength, the force applied on the air column is due to the acceleration of the small mass of the assumedly incompressible air which is contained between the two injection points. The source term is then written as a pressure difference across the window:
prevtext:
with $\sigma$ a proportionality coefficient and $u'$ the fluctuating part of the centerline velocity of the jet described in the previous section. The parameter $\sigma$ can be roughly estimated by assuming momentum conservation between an oscillating Poiseuille profile at the flue exit ($x=0$) and a Bickley profile established downstream, as well as conservation of the centerline velocity (see appendix \ref{app:sigma}). The proportionality coefficient $\sigma$ remains a sensitive parameter that further flow visualisations could focus on.

Finally, the total jet velocity profile at the labium is obtained by combining the transverse displacement due to the anti-symmetric perturbation and the modulation of the thickness due to the symmetric perturbation:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E14.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="U_{W}(y,t)=\frac{\langle u\rangle}{\cosh^{2}\dfrac{y-\eta(W,t)}{b+b^{\prime}(W%
,t)}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>W</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>u</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>cosh</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁡</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>η</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>W</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><msup><mi>b</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>W</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
with $W$ and $H$ the length and the width of the window, respectively. 
 The difference of fluxes depends on the velocity profile at the labium:
prevtext: Once it reaches the labium, the jet is assumed to split into two flows $Q_{in}$ and $Q_{out}$ going toward the interior of the instrument and outwards, respectively. Each flux can be split into a steady and a fluctuating components: $Q_{in} = \langle Q_{in} \rangle + Q_{in}'$ and $Q_{out} = \langle Q_{out} \rangle + Q_{out}'$. The flux are assumed to be injected at specific points, behind the labium, and are separated by an acoustic distance $\delta_d=(4\sqrt{2hW})/\pi$, which is also a sensitive parameter of the model\cite{Verge1994a}. This distance being small compared to the acoustic wavelength, the force applied on the air column is due to the acceleration of the small mass of the assumedly incompressible air which is contained between the two injection points. The source term is then written as a pressure difference across the window:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E15.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\hskip-30.0pt\Delta p_{src}=-\frac{\rho\delta_{d}}{WH}\frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{%
Q_{in}-Q_{out}}{2}\right)," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mpadded lspace="-30pt" width="-30pt"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>p</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>ρ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>d</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>W</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>H</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>Q</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>Q</mi><mrow><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
with $y_0$ the vertical offset between the channel centerline and the labium. The flux $Q_{in}'$ directly depends on the transverse position $\eta$ and the width of the jet $b$ at the labium through Eq. (\ref{eq:Uw}).

Using Eqs. (\ref{eq:Uw}) (\ref{eq:DeltaP_accel}) and (\ref{eq:Qin_integ}) yields the modified source term
prevtext:
with $W$ and $H$ the length and the width of the window, respectively. 
 The difference of fluxes depends on the velocity profile at the labium:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E16.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle Q_{in}(t)-Q_{out}(t)=\\
\displaystyle H\left[\int_{-\infty}^{y_{0}}U_{W}(y,t)dy-\int_{y_{0}}^{\infty}U%
_{W}(y,t)dy\right]," display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>Q</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>Q</mi><mrow><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi/></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></msubsup><mrow><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>W</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><mrow><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>W</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: The total difference of pressure across the window is given by combining Eqs. (\ref{eq:DeltaP_losse}) and (\ref{eq:DeltaP_source}):
prevtext:
with $y_0$ the vertical offset between the channel centerline and the labium. The flux $Q_{in}'$ directly depends on the transverse position $\eta$ and the width of the jet $b$ at the labium through Eq. (\ref{eq:Uw}).

Using Eqs. (\ref{eq:Uw}) (\ref{eq:DeltaP_accel}) and (\ref{eq:Qin_integ}) yields the modified source term
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E17.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\hskip-30.0pt\Delta p_{src}(t)=\\
\displaystyle\frac{\rho\delta_{d}\langle u\rangle}{W}\dfrac{d}{dt}\left[(b+b^{%
\prime}(W,t))\tanh\frac{\eta(W,t)-y_{0}}{b+b^{\prime}(W,t)}\right]." display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mpadded lspace="-30pt" width="-30pt"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>p</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi/></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>ρ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>u</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mrow><mi>W</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><msup><mi>b</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>W</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>tanh</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mi>η</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>W</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><msup><mi>b</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>W</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

prevtext: The total difference of pressure across the window is given by combining Eqs. (\ref{eq:DeltaP_losse}) and (\ref{eq:DeltaP_source}):
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E18.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Delta p=\Delta p_{los}+\Delta p_{src}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>p</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>p</mi><mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>p</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E19.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="I\simeq 20\log\frac{a_{3}}{a_{2}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>≃</mo><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E20.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\int\limits_{-h/2}^{h/2}\rho_{0}(\langle u\rangle+u^{\prime}(t))^%
{2}\left(1-\left(\dfrac{y}{h/2}\right)^{2}\right)^{2}dy=\\
\displaystyle\int\limits_{-\infty}^{\infty}\rho_{0}\left(\dfrac{\langle u%
\rangle}{\cosh^{2}(y/b(t))}\right)^{2}dy," display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>u</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msup><mi>u</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>y</mi><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi/></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>u</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>cosh</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: In the case of small perturbation, these expression can be linearised
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E21.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="b_{0}(t)=\dfrac{2h}{5}\left(2\dfrac{u^{\prime}(t)}{\langle u\rangle}+\left(%
\dfrac{u^{\prime}(t)}{\langle u\rangle}\right)^{2}\right)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>b</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>u</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>u</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>u</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>u</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $\sigma = 4/5$. At cost of approximations and assumptions, it is possible to find a linear relation between fluctuation of jet thickness and fluctuation of jet velocity. Even if this reasoning is a good argument for the validity of the linear relation between these two variables, the numerical value of the proportionality coefficient can't be estimated this way and still remains a sensitive point of the model.
